newsitem.title: USA: World cotton crop 19.61 mln tonnes 97/98--ICAC.
newsitem.headline: World cotton crop 19.61 mln tonnes 97/98--ICAC.

text.p: World cotton production was forecast to rise modestly to 19.61 million tonnes in 1997/98, compared to 19.05 million tonnes for 1996/97, the International Cotton Advisory Committee said Monday.
The increase would be due to a return to average yields in Pakistan and Uzbekistan and larger plantings in Australia and French-speaking Africa, the ICAC said.
Consumption would climb slightly to 19.55 million in 1997/98 from 19 million in 1996/97. End stocks of 9.178 million tonnes in 1996/97 would reach 9.22 in the new marketing year.
As a result of output and usage being approximately in balance, prices would be stable and in the range of 80 cents per lb for 1996/97 and 1997/98.
China was expected to hold nearly half of world stocks at the end of 1996/97, ICAC said.

"Trade policies by China (mainland) have proven difficult to anticipate. If the government...chooses to export some of the cotton now held in storage, there would be a substantial downward impact on cotton prices," ICAC said.
